revision.text:
{{Year box}} [[Image:Lottie Dod age20.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Lottie Dod]] – the youngest ever Wimbledon champion]] '''1887 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Yale Bulldogs football|Yale Bulldogs]] '''Events''' * The rules are changed so that gametime is set at two halves of 45 minutes each (as in [[Association football]]). Two paid officials, a referee and an umpire, are mandated for each game.
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[1887 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] 2–0 [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] at [[The Oval]] * [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley FC]] and [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool FC]] are founded '''Germany''' * [[Hamburger SV]] founded as one of the oldest clubs in Germany '''Scotland''' * [[1887 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] 2–1 [[Dumbarton F.C.|Dumbarton]]
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''Events''' * [[Carlton Football Club]] wins the [[Victorian Football League|Victorian Football Association]] premiership * [[Norwood Football Club]] wins the [[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football Association]] premiership * [[Unions Football Club]] wins the [[West Australian Football League|Western Australian Football Association]] premiership
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National League]] v. [[American Association (19th century)|American Association]] – [[Detroit Wolverines]] (NL) defeats [[Saint Louis Cardinals]] (AA) 10 games to 5 '''Events''' * The two major leagues agree to a unified set of rules. * The [[National Colored Base Ball League]] plays for a few weeks before folding. * Five black men play in the [[International League]], the highest minor league, the high-water mark in racial integration of professional baseball.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hg1si20f?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |archivedate=2009-06-20 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-17 |df= }}</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[John L. Sullivan]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Nonpareil Dempsey]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack McAuliffe (boxer)|Jack McAuliffe]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * The [[English cricket team in Australia in 1886–87]], generally known as [[Alfred Shaw]]'s XI, is described by ''Wisden'' as "one of the strongest that ever left England for the Colonies". The team plays 10 first-class matches, winning 6 with 2 draws and 2 defeats (both against New South Wales). England win both [[Test cricket|Test matches]] played by 13 runs and 71 runs respectively. '''England''' * [[Champion County]]<ref>A semi-official seasonal title proclaimed by media consensus prior to December 1889 when the official County Championship is constituted.</ref> – [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]] * Most runs – [[W. G. Grace]] 2,062 @ 54.26 (HS 183*) * Most wickets – [[George Lohmann]] 154 @ 15.61 (BB 8–36) '''Australia''' * Most runs – [[Arthur Shrewsbury]] 721 @ 48.06 (HS 236) * Most wickets – [[Charles Turner (Australian cricketer)|Charlie Turner]] 70 @ 7.68 (BB 8–32)
==[[Gaelic football]]== * 7 February — Irish forms of football are formally arranged into an organised playing code by the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]], the rules being drawn up by [[Maurice Davin]] and published in the ''United Ireland'' magazine. The GAA seeks to promote traditional Irish sports, such as [[hurling]] and to reject "foreign" (particularly English) imports. * [[Limerick GAA]] wins the inaugural [[All-Ireland Senior Football Championship]].
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1887 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Willie Park, Jnr.|Willie Park junior]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Horace Hutchinson]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1887 Grand National|Grand National]] – Gamecock * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Reve d'Or]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Enterprise (horse)|Enterprise]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Merry Hampton]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Reve d'Or]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Kilwarlin]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Dunlop '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Bonnie Duke '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Eglentine * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Pet Fox '''USA''' * [[1887 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Montrose * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Dunboyne * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Hanover
==[[Hurling]]== * [[Tipperary GAA]] wins the first [[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== * February 25 - The [[Montreal Hockey Club]] defeats [[Montreal Victorias]] 1–0 to win the [[Montreal Winter Carnival ice hockey tournaments#1887|1887 Montreal Winter Carnival Ice Hockey Tournament]]. * March 11 - The [[Montreal Crystals]] defeat the [[Montreal Victorias]] 3–2 to win the inaugural [[1887 AHAC season|1887 AHAC championship]] on the final challenge of the season, despite having a record of two wins and four losses.
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 26 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 44th [[The Boat Race 1887|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * Scotland wins the [[1887 Home Nations Championship]], which is the 5th series
==[[Softball]]== '''Events''' * [[George Hancock (softball)|George Hancock]] invents an indoor baseball game that would become known as softball in [[Chicago, Illinois]] (USA) on November 24.
==[[Tennis]]== '''Events''' * American champion [[Richard Sears (tennis player)|Richard D. Sears]] retires from the sport after winning the US singles title for the seventh successive time, a record that still stands '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Herbert Lawford]] (GB) defeats [[Ernest Renshaw]] (GB) 1–6 6–3 3–6 6–4 6–4 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Lottie Dod]] (GB) defeats [[Blanche Bingley]] (GB) 6–2 6–0 '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Richard Sears (tennis player)|Richard D. Sears]] (USA) defeats [[Henry Slocum (tennis player)|Henry Slocum]] (USA) 6–1 6–3 6–2 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Ellen Hansell]] (USA) defeats [[Laura Knight (tennis)|Laura Knight]] (USA) 6–1 6–0
==[[Yacht racing]]== '''America's Cup''' * The [[New York Yacht Club]] retains the [[America's Cup]] as [[Volunteer (yacht)|''Volunteer'']] defeats British challenger ''[[Thistle (yacht)|Thistle]]'', of the [[Royal Clyde Yacht Club]], 2 races to 0
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1887 in sports| ]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2013}} {| class="infobox" style="width: 23em; font-size: 90%" ! colspan="2" style="text-align: center; font-size: larger;" |'''2nd Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race''' |- |style="text-align: right;|'''Date''' |26 December 1946 – 4 January 1947 |- |style="text-align: right;|'''Defender''' |''Rani'' |- |'''Number of yachts''' |19 |- |'''Coordinates''' |{{coord|33|51.35|S|151|12.40|E|region:AU_type:landmark|display=inline,title}}-
{{coord|42|52.7|S|147|19.58|E|region:AU_type:landmark|display=inline}} |- |'''Winner''' |''Morna'' |} The '''1946 Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race''' was the second annual running of the "blue water classic" [[Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article22387699 |title=Sydney-Hobart Race Begins Today. |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=26 December 1946 |accessdate=27 December 2013 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} It was hosted by the [[Cruising Yacht Club of Australia]] based in [[Sydney]]. The inaugural race in 1945 had been planned as a [[cruising (maritime)|cruise]], and no thoughts were given to repeating the event. However it became a race at the suggestion of visiting [[Royal Navy]] captain John Illingworth, and the race proved so popular a repeat was planned. The second race began on [[Port Jackson|Sydney Harbour]], at noon on [[Boxing Day]] (26 December 1946), before heading south for 630 nautical miles (1,170 km) through the [[Tasman Sea]], past [[Bass Strait]], into [[Storm Bay]] and up the [[Derwent River, Tasmania|Derwent River]], to cross the finish line in [[Hobart, Tasmania]]. The 1946 expanded fleet comprised more than double the vessels of the inaugural event with19 starters. Of the 19 starters, 8 yachts were forced to retire, and the remaining 11 made it successfully to Hobart, with ''Morna'' captained by Claude Plowman winning line honours, and ''Christina'' captained by JR Bull taking handicap honours on adjusted time.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article69066004 |title=MORNA FIRST ACROSS LINE IN YACHT RACE. |newspaper=[[The Advocate (Tasmania)|The Advocate]] |location=Burnie, Tas. |date=1 January 1948 |accessdate=26 December 2013 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} ==1946 fleet== 19 yachts registered to begin the 1946 Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race. The '''1978 WBF World Championships''' took place in November 1978 in [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]]. {{Infobox football league season |competition = [[Liga I Feminin]] |season = 2010–11 |winners = [[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia Cluj]] (1st title) |relegated = |continentalcup1 = [[2011–12 UEFA Women's Champions League|Champions League]] |continentalcup1 qualifiers = [[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia Cluj]] |league topscorer = [[Cosmina Duşa]] |biggest home win = [[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia Cluj]] 27–0 [[AFC Fair Play Bucureşti|Fair Play Bucureşti]] (8 May 2011) |biggest away win = [[FC Alice & Tunes Piteşti|Alice & Tunes Piteşti]] 0–19 [[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia Cluj]] (24 October 2010) |highest scoring = [[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia Cluj]] 27–0 [[AFC Fair Play Bucureşti|Fair Play Bucureşti]] (8 May 2011) |matches = 156 |total goals = 906 |longest wins = 24 games
[[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia Cluj]]
(whole season) |longest unbeaten = |longest losses = |highest attendance = |lowest attendance = |average attendance = |prevseason = [[2009–10 Liga I (women's football)|2009-10]] |nextseason = [[2011–12 Liga I Feminin|2011–12]] }} The '''2010–11 season of the [[Liga I Feminin]]''' was the 21st season of [[Romania]]'s premier women's [[football (soccer)|football]] league. The season started on 18 September 2010 and ended on 12 June 2011.{{cite web|title=2010/11 season|url=https://int.soccerway.com/national/romania/campionatul-national/2010-2011/regular-season/|publisher=women.soccerway.com|accessdate=7 July 2011}} Olimpia Cluj won the championship in its first season. Olimpia's striker [[Cosmina Duşa]] scored over 100 goals this season.{{cite web|title=Olimpia Cluj a castigat Cupa Romaniei la fotbal feminin|url=http://www.ziare.com/fotbal/fotbal-rezultate/olimpia-cluj-a-castigat-cupa-romaniei-la-fotbal-feminin-1097117|publisher=ziare.com|accessdate=10 June 2011|language=Romanian|date=26 May 2011}} == Teams == [[FC Inter SMEF Sibiu|Inter Sibiu]] and [[CS Intercredo Piteşti|Intercredo Piteşti]] withdrew form the championship after the end of the last season. New teams entered the first league: [[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia Cluj]], [[CS Real Craiova|Real Craiova]], [[CS Brazi]] and [[FC Nicolae Dobrin]]. After the first round [[Smart Sport Bucureşti]] withdrew due to financial problems. Another team that withdrew, but after the half season, was [[FC Nicolae Dobrin]]. They lost all their remaining matches with 3-0. ===Stadia and locations=== {{Location map+ |Romania |float=right |width=400 |caption=Location of clubs in '''Liga I feminin 2010–11''' |places= {{location map~ |Romania |lat=46.779139 |long=23.599663 |label=[[CFF Clujana|Clujana]]}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=46.779139 |long=23.599663 |label=[[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia]]|position=left}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=44.32876 |long=23.812866 |label=[[CS Real Craiova|Real]]|position=bottom}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=44.32876 |long=23.812866 |label=[[FC Sporting Craiova|Sporting]]|position=left}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=46.544458 |long=24.566975 |label=[[FCM Târgu Mureș (feminin)|Târgu Mureş]]}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=44.94 |long=26.03 |label=[[CS Brazi|Brazi]]|position=right}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=47.072222 |long=21.921111 |label=[[CS Motorul Oradea|Motorul]]}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=46.35 |long=25.53 |label=[[CS Metalul Vlăhiţa|Metalul]]}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=44.924167 |long=25.456667 |label=[[CSS Târgovişte|Târgovişte]]|position=top}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=44.860556 |long=24.867778 |label=[[FC Alice & Tunes Piteşti|Alice&Tunes]]|position=bottom}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=44.860556 |long=24.867778 |label=[[FC Nicolae Dobrin|Dobrin]]|position=left}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=44.4325 |long=26.103889 |label=[[AFC Fair Play Bucureşti|Fair Play]]|position=right}} {{location map~ |Romania |lat=44.173333 |long=28.638333 |label=[[CS Şantierul Naval Constanţa|Şantierul Naval]]|position=right}} }} {| class="wikitable sortable" ! page.title: Bahamas at the 2013 World Championships in Athletics

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox country at games | IAAF = BAH | fedname = | year = 2013 | games = World Championships in Athletics | location = [[Moscow]] | competitors = 26 | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | rank = | previous = [[Bahamas at the 2011 World Championships in Athletics|2011]] | next = [[Bahamas at the 2015 World Championships in Athletics|2015]] | website = }} '''[[Bahamas]]''' is competing at the '''[[2013 World Championships in Athletics]]''' in Moscow, Russia, from 10–18 August 2013. A team of 26 athletes was announced to represent the country in the event. {{ Citation | last = | first = | date = 2 August 2013 | title = Athletes – 14th IAAF World Championships | url = {{Infobox tennis cup team | Name = Barbados | Type = Davis | Image = Flag of Barbados.svg | Nickname = | Captain = | Coach = | ITF Rank = 41 {{down}} (September 2017) | ITF max = | ITF max date = | ITF min = | ITF min date = | Colors = Blue and yellow | First year = 1990 | Years played = 28 | Ties played = 113 (49–64) | WG played = | Titles = | Runners-up = | Best = | Player wins = [[Haydn Lewis]] (46–29) | Singles wins = [[Darian King]] (28–7) | Doubles wins = Haydn Lewis (20–13) | Best doubles = Darian King &
Haydn Lewis (10–6) | Most ties = Haydn Lewis (47) | Most years = Haydn Lewis (14) }} The '''Barbados Davis Cup team''' represents [[Barbados]] in [[Davis Cup]] [[tennis]] competition and are governed by the [[Barbados Tennis Association]]. ==History== Barbados competed in its first Davis Cup in [[1990 Davis Cup|1990]]. Barbadian players previously competed on the [[Caribbean/West Indies Davis Cup team|Caribbean/West Indies team]]. In 1990, Barbados debuted in Group II of the Americas Zone (the lowest tier at that time). In [[2014 Davis Cup Americas Zone Group II|2014]], they upset [[Mexico Davis Cup team|Mexico]] to advance to Group I of the Americas Zone for the first time in their history. They were relegated in [[2016 Davis Cup|2016]], but managed promotion back into Group I in [[2017 Davis Cup|2017]]. ==Current team (2017)== * [[Darian King]] * [[Haydn Lewis]] (amateur player) * [[Adam Hornby]] (amateur player) * [[Matthew Foster-Estwick]] (amateur player) ==See also== *[[Davis Cup]] *[[Barbados Fed Cup team]] ==External links== {{DavisCupteamlink|code=BAR}} {{National sports teams of Barbados}} {{Davis Cup}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barbados Davis Cup Team}} [[Category:Davis Cup teams]] [[Category:National sports teams of Barbados|Davis Cup]] [[Category:Tennis in Barbados|Davis Cup]] {{Barbados-sport-stub}} {{DavisCup-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Schaumburg Boomers Stadium | nickname = | image = Schaumburg Boomers Stadium 2017-06-19.jpg | caption = The outside of Boomers Stadium in June 2017 | location = 1999 South Springinsguth Road
[[Schaumburg, Illinois]] 60193 | coordinates = | broke_ground = July 10, 1998{{cite news |title=A Groundbreaking Day For `Mini' Wrigley Field|first=Carri|last=Karuhn|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-07-10/news/9807100137_1_stadium-wrigley-field-field-dimensions|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=July 10, 1998|accessdate=February 4, 2012}} | built = | opened = {{Start date and age|1999|5|27}}{{cite news |title=Schaumburg Flyers Ready To Play Ball|first=Mark|last=Mandernach|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1999-05-23/features/9905230048_1_big-dates-baseball-fans-schaumburg-flyers|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=May 23, 1999|accessdate=February 4, 2012}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Village of Schaumburg & Schaumburg Park District | operator = Schaumburg Boomers Professional Baseball | surface = Natural grass | construction_cost = $19 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|19000000|1999}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Sink Combs Dethlefs | general_contractor= [[Turner Construction]] | former_names = Schaumburg Baseball Stadium (1999)
Alexian Field (2000-2011) | tenants = [[Schaumburg Boomers]] ([[Frontier League|FL]]) (2012-present)
[[Schaumburg Flyers]] ([[Northern League (baseball, 1993–2010)|NL]]) (1999-2010)
[[Chicago Tornadoes]] ([[Pro Cricket]]) (2004)
Dominican Stars ([[NCAA Division III|NCAA]]) (2008-present)
Wheaton Thunder ([[NCAA Division III|NCAA]]) (2009-2010)
[[Roosevelt Lakers]] ([[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]]) (2011-2012) | seating_capacity = [[Baseball]]: 7,365[http://www.boomersbaseball.com/stadium/default/ Stadium - Boomers Stadium] | dimensions = Left - 355'
Left-center - 368'
Center - 400'
Right-center - 368'
Right - 353' }} '''Schaumburg Boomers Stadium''' often referred to simply as '''Boomers Stadium''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Schaumburg, Illinois]], formerly known as '''Alexian Field'''. It is now home to the [[Schaumburg Boomers]] of the [[Frontier League]] which began play in May 2012 and captured the first-ever professional baseball championship for Schaumburg in 2013. It is primarily used for [[baseball]], and was the home field of the [[Schaumburg Flyers]] baseball team from 1999 through 2010 before the Boomers resurrected the facility for pro baseball in 2012. Schaumburg Boomers Stadium opened in 1999 and the park holds 7,365 people for a baseball game or over 10,000 for a concert or other non-baseball event. Its field dimensions mimic those of Chicago's [[Wrigley Field]], and the land the stadium is built on was originally purchased in the mid-1980s as a hopeful site for the '''New Wrigley Field''', had the [[City of Chicago]] and the [[Chicago Cubs]] not come to terms to bring night baseball to the North Side. Some pro [[lacrosse]] as well as [[Major North American professional sports teams|professional]] and [[amateur]] softball has also been played at Schaumburg Boomers Stadium due to the late start (mid-May) of the independent baseball season. The Stadium itself is located west of [[Interstate 355|I-355]] off the [[Elgin-O'Hare Expressway]]. Now called '''Schaumburg Boomers Stadium,''' the [[Alexian Brothers]] Medical Center in nearby [[Elk Grove Village, Illinois|Elk Grove]] purchased the naming rights to the ballpark in 2000. The Stadium was host to the [[Schaumburg Flyers]] from its opening through the end of the 2010 season. At that point, the village and park district which owned the stadium began eviction proceedings against the Flyers for failure to pay $551,800 in back rent. On February 24, 2011, a [[Cook County, Illinois|Cook County]] court ruled the Flyers could be evicted, ordered the now defunct team to pay the back rent, and the naming rights contract was terminated when there was no professional baseball played in the park in 2011. From 2009-10, the Wheaton College Thunder, a Division III baseball program, played its home games at Schaumburg Boomers Stadium, and since 2008 the Dominican University Stars another Division III baseball program has played a majority of it home games at Schaumburg Boomers Stadium. In 2011, the [[Roosevelt University#Athletics|Roosevelt Lakers]], an NAIA baseball program, played its home games at the stadium as well. Later that year, in September 2011, Chicago attorney [[Patrick A. Salvi]] was awarded ownership of a [[Frontier League]] franchise that began play in May 2012. Salvi is also the owner of the American Association's [[Gary SouthShore RailCats]]. The franchise is known as the '''Schaumburg Boomers''' named after the "booming dance" of the male Greater Prairie Chicken and the team earned a 54-42 record during its Inaugural Season, falling one win short of a playoff berth. In just the franchise's second season in 2013, the Schaumburg Boomers captured the first-ever pro baseball championship for the Village of Schaumburg in impressive fashion. After capturing the league's best record in the regular season (59-37), the Boomers became the first team in the Frontier League's 14-year history to sweep through the playoffs with a 6-0 record en route to claiming the 2013 Frontier League Championship. In doing so, the Boomers made good on a promise to win title in the "first 100 years or your money back." The guarantee was featured on a billboard announcing the new team in March 2012 before the club's first season got underway.http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20130917/sports/709179692/ ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.boomersbaseball.com Official Site of the Schaumburg Boomers] * [http://www.ballparkreviews.com/schaumb/schaumb.htm BallparkReviews.com Photos and Review] * [http://www.rooseveltlakers.com/sport/0/3.php Roosevelt Lakers web page] * [http://athletics.wheaton.edu/index.aspx?tab=baseball&path=baseball Wheaton Thunder web page] {{coord|41|59|34.18|N|88|7|5.12|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=title}} {{Frontier League Ballparks}} [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in the United States]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Roosevelt Lakers]] [[Category:Softball venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Schaumburg, Illinois]] [[Category:Sports venues in Cook County, Illinois]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1999]] [[Category:Cricket in Illinois]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox stadium |stadium_name = Green Point Stadium |nick_name = |image = File:Cape_Town_Stadium_Aerial_View.jpg |location = Fritz Sonnenberg Road, [[Green Point, Cape Town]], South Africa |coordinates = {{Coord|33|54|12.46|S|18|24|40.15|E|type:landmark_scale:3000_region:ZA|}} |broke_ground = 26 March 2007 |opened = 14 December 2009 |owner = City of Cape Town |surface = Grass |general_contractor = [[Murray & Roberts]]/ WBHO |construction_cost = [[South African Rand|R]] 4.4 billion
([[United States dollar|USD $]] 600 million
[[Pound sterling|£]] 415 million) |architect = GMP Architects, Louis Karol Architects, Point Architects |former_names = |seating_capacity = 55,000 |dimensions = 290 × 265 × 48 m{{cite web|url=http://www.capetownmagazine.com/news/68-000-Seats-2-300-Workers-1-New-Green-Point-Stadium/10_22_10140|title=Green Point Stadium – FIFA 2010 World Cup – Green Point Stadium Cape Town|publisher=|accessdate=16 September 2014}} |tenants = [[Ajax Cape Town F.C.]] (2010–present)
[[Cape Town City F.C. (2016)|Cape Town City F.C.]] (2016–present) }} The '''Cape Town Stadium''' ({{lang-af|Kaapstad-stadion}}; {{lang-xh|Inkundla yezemidlalo yaseKapa}}){{cite web|url=http://www.capetown.gov.za/en/Pages/Thecitys2010FIFAWorldCupstadiumhasanewnameCapeTownStadium.aspx|title=The city's 2010 FIFA World Cup stadium has a new name: Cape Town Stadium|first=Martin|last=Pollack|date=30 October 2009|publisher=City of Cape Town|access-date=21 May 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727104233/http://www.capetown.gov.za/en/Pages/Thecitys2010FIFAWorldCupstadiumhasanewnameCapeTownStadium.aspx#|archive-date=27 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} in [[Cape Town]], South Africa is a stadium that was built for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]].{{cite web|url= http://www.shine2010.co.za/Community/blogs/goodnews/archive/2009/12/17/cape-town-s-green-point-stadium-completed-keys-handed-over.aspx|title=Stadium Complete|publisher=Shine 2010|date=17 December 2009}} During the planning stage, it was known as the '''Green Point Stadium''', which was the name of the [[Green Point Stadium|previous stadium]] on the site, and this name was also used frequently during World Cup media coverage. It is the home ground of [[Premier Soccer League]] clubs [[Ajax Cape Town F.C.|Ajax Cape Town]] (since 2010) and [[Cape Town City F.C. (2016)|Cape Town City]] (since 2016). It has also hosted the [[South Africa Sevens]] rugby tournament since 2015. The stadium is located in [[Green Point, Cape Town|Green Point]], between [[Signal Hill (Cape Town)|Signal Hill]] and the [[Atlantic Ocean]], close to the Cape Town city centre and to the [[Victoria & Alfred Waterfront]], a popular tourist and shopping venue. The stadium had a seating capacity of 64,100 during the 2010 World Cup,{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/destination/stadiums/stadium=5011924/index.html|title=Cape Town Stadium|accessdate=2 December 2011|publisher=FIFA}} later reduced to 55,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/africa/countries/south_africa.shtml|title=worldstadiums.com – Stadiums in South Africa|publisher=|accessdate=16 September 2014}} The stadium is connected to the waterfront by a new road connection, Granger Bay Boulevard. ==Name== {{Location map |Cape Town |label = Green Point Stadium |alt = The stadium is in Green Point, on the Atlantic coast just west of the Cape Town city centre. |position = |lon_dir = E |lat_dir = S |lat_deg = 33 |lat_min = 54 |lat_sec = 12.46 |lon_deg = 18 |lon_min = 24 |lon_sec = 40.15 |mark = |marksize = |caption = Location of the stadium in the Cape Town metropolitan area |float = right |width = 180 }} During construction, Cape Town Stadium was unofficially known as Green Point Stadium, the name of [[Green Point Stadium|an older stadium]] demolished to make way for the new stadium. During October 2009, the city asked for the public to propose names for the new stadium and the name Cape Town Stadium was chosen. In December 2017, plans for a new name were underway. ==Previous stadium== {{multiple image |align =right |direction=vertical |header =The old stadium |header_align=center |header_background= |footer = |footer_align=center |footer_background= |width =180 |image1 =Green Point - Cape Town - Boer War - Transit Camp.jpg |width1 = |alt1 = |caption1 =The beginnings of the former Green Point Stadium during the Second Boer War |image2 =Old greenpoint stadium.jpg |width2 = |alt2 = |caption2 =Aerial view of the old [[Green Point Stadium]], which was partly demolished during 2007}} The stadium is adjacent to the site of the original 18,000 seater stadium [[Green Point Stadium]]. It replaces a portion of the Metropolitan Golf Club site which has now been realigned. The previous stadium, which was partly demolished in 2007, was a [[multi-purpose stadium]] used mainly for football matches, and was the home ground of [[Santos Football Club (South Africa)|Santos Football Club]] and [[Ajax Cape Town FC|Ajax Cape Town]] at different points. It also hosted music concerts, including the November 2003 [[46664 (concerts)|46664 Concert]] for the benefit of AIDS victims.{{cite web | url = http://www.sabc.co.za/mandela/featuredetails/56b01600474ee6f6b206fa7dca15ccff/group5 | title = The 46664 campaign | work = South African Broadcasting Corporation | date = 2011-06-21 | accessdate = 2016-04-04 }} The section of the old stadium that remained was redeveloped into the Green Point Athletics Stadium, which opened in 2015 with a seating capacity of 4500.{{cite web | url = http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/western-cape/green-point-athletics-stadium-opens-1820739 | title = Green Point Athletics Stadium opens | author = Anel Lewis | date = 2015-02-19 | accessdate = 2016-04-04 }} ==Design== [[File:Cape Town Stadium.jpg|thumbnail|An aerial view of the stadium from just above its roof.]] [[File:Capetown stadium.JPG|thumb|Cape Town stadium viewed from [[Signal Hill (Cape Town)|Signal Hill]]]] Construction of the Cape Town Stadium, located on the [[Green Point Common]], began in March 2007. In 33 months, joint contractors Murray & Roberts and WBHO completed the project at a cost of R4.4billion – or approximately US$600million. The project architects were an association between GMP Architects of Germany and two local firms, Louis Karol and Associates and Point Architects. The structural engineers comprised a joint venture between BKS, Henry Fagan & Partners, KFD Wilkinson, Goba, Iliso and Arcus Gibb.{{cite web|url=http://www.capetown.travel/2010/faq/stadium/|title=CT Stadium Construction Information|accessdate=9 January 2010}} ==Handing over== Cape Town Stadium was officially handed over to the [[City of Cape Town]] on schedule on 14 December 2009. At a ceremony in front of over 200 invited guests and the media representatives from around the world, Cape Town Executive Mayor Alderman Dan Plato, received the keys to the stadium officially confirming the opening of Cape Town Stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.capetown.gov.za/en/FIFA2010/Newsandmedia/Pages/CapeTownStadiumhandedoveronschedule.aspx|publisher=City of Cape Town|title=Cape Town Stadium Opening|accessdate=9 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100216194911/http://www.capetown.gov.za/en/FIFA2010/Newsandmedia/Pages/CapeTownStadiumhandedoveronschedule.aspx|archivedate=16 February 2010|df=dmy-all}} ==Usage after the World Cup== A consortium consisting of South Africa's Sail Group and French-based Stade de France were awarded the service contract to operate the stadium and ensure that it remains a sustainable multi-purpose venue after the 2010 FIFA World Cup. The consortium, called Business Venture Investments 1317, was involved in the management of the stadium from January 2009 onwards. The city municipality paid the consortium to manage the stadium up to and during the World Cup, after which the consortium will lease the stadium from the city for a period of not less than 10 years and not more than 30 years.{{Cite web | last = Warby | first = Vivian | authorlink = | author2 = | title = Greenpoint stadium operator chosen | work = | publisher = | date = 1 December 2008 | url = http://www.southafrica.info/2010/greenpoint-011208.htm | doi = | accessdate = 11 April 2011 }} Following the World Cup, temporary rows of seating on either side on the top tier were replaced by events suites and clubrooms, reducing the stadium's capacity to 55,000.{{cite web | url = http://www.dezeen.com/2010/06/08/green-point-stadium-by-gmp-architekten/ | title = Green Point Stadium by GMP Architekten | date = 8 June 2010 | accessdate = 2016-04-02 }} The stadium features corporate hospitality suites, medical, training, and conferencing and banqueting facilities. The consortium will operate the stadium as well as manage and maintain the defined areas of the surrounding urban park and sport precinct on the 85-hectare Greenpoint Common from stadium revenue.{{cite web|url=http://www.southafrica.info/2010/greenpoint-011208.htm|title=Greenpoint stadium operator chosen|publisher=SouthAfrica.info|date=1 December 2008|accessdate=9 January 2010}} [[Ajax Cape Town]] have used the stadium as their home ground from the [[2010-11 Premier Soccer League]] (PSL) season onwards.{{cite web|url=http://www.kickoff.com/news/16497/ajax-lused-cape-town-stadium.php|title=Chiefs to use Rand Stadium this season|publisher=KickOff Magazine|date=30 June 2010|accessdate=8 July 2010}} Due to the stadium's ongoing financial problems, the City of Cape Town had sought to acquire [[Western Province (rugby team)|Western Province rugby]] as an "anchor tenant". After four years of talks, Western Province announced in December 2014 that they had decided to remain at [[Newlands Stadium]].{{cite news|last1=Lewis|first1=Anel|title=WP says no to Cape Town Stadium|url=http://www.iol.co.za/sport/rugby/wp-says-no-to-cape-town-stadium-1.1797241#.VcvHl_lVhHw|accessdate=12 August 2015|work=IOL Sport|date=19 December 2014}} In March 2015, the [[South African Rugby Union]] announced that the [[South Africa Sevens]] tournament would be staged at Cape Town Stadium for four years, beginning in December 2015.{{cite news|title=Green Point becomes new Sevens heaven|url=http://www.supersport.com/rugby/sevens/news/150320/Green_Point_becomes_new_Sevens_heaven|accessdate=12 August 2015|work=SuperSport|date=20 March 2015}} In June 2016, it was announced that new PSL club [[Cape Town City F.C. (2016)|Cape Town City]] would also play at Cape Town Stadium.{{cite news|last1=Said|first1=Nick|title=PSL newcomers Cape Town City FC finally launched in the Mother City|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sport/soccer/2016/06/29/PSL-newcomers-Cape-Town-City-FC-finally-launched-in-the-Mother-City|accessdate=30 June 2016|work=Times Live|date=29 June 2016}} ==Inaugural games== The first game to be hosted at the new Cape Town Stadium was a Cape Town derby between [[Ajax Cape Town]] and [[Engen Santos|Santos]] on 23 January 2010 as part of the official inauguration of the stadium. Only 20,000 tickets were made available for the event and were sold out by Friday 15 January 2010. The Soccer Festival had entertainment from local band [[Freshlyground]] and a [[Vuvuzela]] orchestra performance during half time. {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:100%;" |- !Date !Time ([[South African Standard Time|SAST]]) !Team 1 !Res. !Team 2 !Attendance |- |23 January 2010||16:00||{{flagicon|RSA}} [[Ajax Cape Town]]||style="text-align:center;"|0–0
(5–6 [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|pen.]])||{{flagicon|RSA}} [[Engen Santos|Santos]]|| style="text-align:center;" |20,000 |} The second of three 'dry runs' at the new Cape Town Stadium was another Cape Town derby. Local Cape Town rugby teams, The [[Stormers|Vodacom Stormers]] and the [[Boland Cavaliers|Boland Inv. XV]] battled it out at the Cape Town Rugby Festival that took place on 6 February 2010. The Rugby Festival had entertainment from local band [[Flat Stanley]]. Only 40,000 tickets were made available for the event. This was double the amount that attended the Soccer Festival. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:100%;" |- !Date !Time ([[South African Standard Time|SAST]]) !Team 1 !Res. !Team 2 !Attendance |- |6 February 2010||16:15||{{flagicon|RSA}} [[Stormers|Vodacom Stormers]]||style="text-align:center;"|47–13||{{flagicon|RSA}} [[Boland Cavaliers|Boland Inv. XV]]||style="text-align:center;"|40,000 |} Cape Town Stadium hosted its third test event on Monday 22 March, during which all 55,000 permanent seats were available for the first time. A total of 52,000 tickets were sold. ‘Cape Town For Jesus', a religious gathering addressed by South African evangelist [[Angus Buchan]], was the first major non-sporting event hosted at the stadium, and gave the stadium operators another chance to test their readiness ahead of the 2010 FIFA World Cup. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:100%;" |- !Date !Time ([[South African Standard Time|SAST]]) !Event !Capacity !Attendance |- |22 March 2010||13:00||Cape Town For Jesus||style="text-align:center;"|55,000||style="text-align:center;"|52,000 |} Cape Town Stadium hosted its fourth and final test event on Saturday 10 April. This was the first time that the stadium was utilised at night, for the International Under-20 Soccer Challenge between South Africa, Brazil, Nigeria and Ghana. About 40,000 attended the event that tested the stadium's readiness for the 2010 FIFA World Cup. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:100%;" |- !Date !Time ([[South African Standard Time|SAST]]) !Team 1 !Res. !Team 2 !Attendance |- |10 April 2010||18:00||{{flagicon|GHA}} [[Ghana national under-20 football team|Ghana U-20]]||style="text-align:center;"|0–1||{{flagicon|BRA}} [[Brazil national under-20 football team|Brazil U-20]]||style="text-align:center;"|40,000 |- |10 April 2010||20:30||{{flagicon|RSA}} [[South Africa national under-20 football team|South Africa U-20]]||style="text-align:center;"|1–3||{{flagicon|NGR}} [[Nigeria national under-20 football team|Nigeria U-20]]||style="text-align:center;"|40,000 |} ==2010 FIFA World Cup== In the World Cup, Cape Town Stadium hosted five first round matches, one second round, one quarter-final, and one semi-final.{{cite web|url=http://www.southafrica.info/2010/2010-faq.htm|title=2010 Fifa World Cup: success stories|publisher=SouthAfrica.info|accessdate=26 May 2007}} During the World Cup, all FIFA media referred to the stadium as 'Green Point Stadium'. ===Matches=== {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" Netherlands|Semi-finals]]||style="text-align:center;"|62,479 |} ==International friendlies== On 17 November 2010, the Cape Town Stadium hosted its first [[exhibition game|international friendly]]. The match was between [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]] and the [[United States men's national soccer team|USA]], where they played for the Nelson Mandela Challenge Trophy. of a possible move of the Super rugby team [[Stormers]] to the Cape Town Stadium.{{cite web | url = http://www.superxv.com/wp-stormers-renew-talks-to-move-stadium/ | title = WP & Stormers renew talks |[[Mariah Carey]] |[[The Sweet Sweet Fantasy Tour]] |style="text-align:center;"|35,000 |- |2017 |17 May |Justin Bieber |[[Purpose World Tour]] |style="text-align:center;"|39,706 |} ==Movies== Cape Town Stadium was featured in the film ''[[Safe House (2012 film)|Safe House]]'' (2012). The stadium also features in many local advertising and print media campaigns.{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/safe-house-how-one-film-put-cape-towns-movie-industry-on-the-map-7851268.html|title=Safe House: How one film put Cape Town's movie industry on the map|website=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-04-07}} ==Incidents== On 7 November 2012, shortly before the U.S rock band [[Linkin Park]] was set to perform at the sold-out stadium, gusts of wind caused advertising scaffolding outside the stadium to collapse onto a crowd of people injuring 19 and killing 1; of the 19 injured, 12 were taken to hospital for further treatment.{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/news/general_music_news/one_dead_and_several_injured_at_linkin_park_show_in_cape_town.html|title=One Dead And Several Injured at Linkin Park Show in Cape Town - Music News @ Ultimate-Guitar.Com|publisher=|accessdate=16 September 2014}} ==Calls for demolition== Several individuals and groups have called for the stadium to be demolished due to its under-utilization after the World Cup. Effective utilization and use of the stadium is thus a political issue in the city.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/tear-down-cape-town-stadium-1327924|title=‘Tear down Cape Town Stadium’ {{!}} IOL|website=IOL|access-date=2016-04-18}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/western-cape/cape-town-stadium-icon-or-albatross-1867226|title=Cape Town Stadium: icon or albatross {{!}} IOL|website=IOL|access-date=2016-04-18}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/opinion/why-cape-town-stadium-should-be-demolished|title=Why Cape Town stadium should be demolished - OPINION {{!}} Politicsweb|website=www.politicsweb.co.za|access-date=2016-04-18}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Cape Town Stadium}} * [http://www.capetown.gov.za/en/CapeTownStadium2/Pages/default.aspx Cape Town Stadium] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100127080229/http://www.capetown.gov.za/en/FIFA2010/Pages/CapeTownStadium.aspx Cape Town Stadium] City of Cape Town FIFA 2010 website * [http://www.capetown.travel/2010/capetown-stadium/stadium/ Cape Town Stadium] Cape Town Tourism website * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100423065150/http://in3sixty.com/cms/manager/share/id/4d76d42b-fd48-aef7-a57a-7905ad61dbaf 360 View] * [http://www.360southafrica.com/virtual-tours-of-attractions/cape-town-stadium 360 degree Virtual Tour (5 locations)] 360SouthAfrica {{Coord|33|54|12.46|S|18|24|40.15|E|region:ZA-WC_type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=title}} {{Premier Soccer League venues}} {{World Cup 2010 stadiums}} {{World sevens series}} {{Ajax Cape Town FC}} [[Category:Soccer venues in South Africa]] [[Category:Sports venues in Cape Town]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] [[Category:Ajax Cape Town F.C.]] [[Category:2010 FIFA World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Music venues in South Africa]] [[Category:Gerkan, Marg and Partners buildings]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in South Africa]] [[Category:Cape Town City F.C. revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{one source|date=December 2011}} {{Infobox Sport governing body |assocname= Cricket Scotland |abbrev = |logo= Cricket_Scotland_logo.png |sport= [[Cricket]] |category = |image = |caption = |jurisdiction = [[Cricket in Scotland]] |founded = {{Start date|1908}} |aff = |affdate = |region = |regionyear = |headquarters = [[Edinburgh]] |location = [[Scotland]] |president = |chairman = Tony Brian |chiefexec = Malcolm Cannon |secretary = |coach = [[Grant Bradburn]] |womenscoach = |key staff = |operating income = |sponsor = [[Nuffield Health]], [[Parkmead Group]], [[Citylets]], [[Canterbury of New Zealand|Canterbury]], [[Abellio ScotRail|ScotRail]], [[Murgitroyd]] |year closed = |replaced = |prevfounded = |url = http://www.cricketscotland.com/ |countryflag=Scotland |countryflag2= }} '''Cricket Scotland''', formerly known as the '''Scottish Cricket Union''', is the [[Sport governing body|governing body]] of the sport of [[cricket in Scotland]]. The body is based at the National Cricket Academy, Edinburgh.
The SCU was formed in 1908, but underwent a major restructuring in 2001 including a name change. It became an [[International Cricket Council]] member in 1994 as an Associate nation. It has three sub-associations: [[East of Scotland Cricket Association]], Western District Cricket Union and the Aberdeenshire Cricket Association.
==Structure== The governing body for cricket in Scotland is Cricket Scotland which was formed in 1908 as the Scottish Cricket Union, but re-structured in 2001. The work of Cricket Scotland includes the organisation and administration of national representative sides (senior and youth, men and women); the organisation of District/Area cricket; the organisation of national club cup competitions; the Scottish National Cricket Leagues; a national coaching programme for elite squads and at grass roots level; coach education; advice to members on relevant issues; and generally developing and promoting the game in Scotland. There are 150 cricket clubs affiliated to Cricket Scotland, but in total it is estimated that there are well over 250 clubs in Scotland.
Cricket Scotland employs 3 full-time and one part-time Cricket Development Officers covering the whole of Scotland. These Development officers work in association with local clubs, schools and associations in running coaching courses and coach education throughout the country, setting up leagues introducing new initiatives such as 'Inter-cricket' and '[[Kwik- Cricket]]'.
The Scottish season runs from mid-April to early September, with almost all senior cricket being played on grass pitches. League cricket is mainly played on Saturdays whilst Sundays sees the majority of cup competitions played. Mid-week cricket is also becoming more popular for friendly matches as the demand for pitches at weekends grows.<ref> [http://www.cricketscotland.com/SCOTLAND/DATABASE/SCL/structure.shtml Structure] Official Website. Retrieved 22 January 2012</ref>
==Name change== After the organisation was founded in 1908, it was known as the Scottish Cricket Union. This was renamed as Cricket Scotland in 2001.
== Hall of Fame ==
In November 2011, Cricket Scotland introduced to legends of Scottish cricket who played an integral part in the development of Scottish cricket.<ref>[http://www.espncricinfo.com/scotland/content/story/542926.html Scottish cricket launches Hall of Fame]</ref><ref>[http://www.cricketscotland.com/corporate/scottish-cricket-hall-fame/ Cricket Scotland for inductees]</ref><ref>[http://www.cricketscotland.com/news/article/new-scottish-cricket-hall-fame-inductees/ NEW SCOTTISH CRICKET HALL OF FAME INDUCTEES]</ref>
* [[Leslie Balfour]] * [[Gregor MacGregor (sportsman)|Gregor MacGregor]] * [[John Kerr (Scottish cricketer)|John Kerr]] * [[James Aitchison (cricketer)|James Aitchison]] * [[Jimmy Allan (cricketer)|Jimmy Allan]] * [[Mike Denness]] * [[George Goddard (cricketer)|George Goddard]] * [[Brian Hardie]] * [[Iain Philip]] * [[Dougie Brown]] * [[Gavin Hamilton (cricketer)|Gavin Hamilton]] * [[Craig Wright (cricketer)|Craig Wright]] * [[James Brown (cricketer)|James Brown]] * [[Ryan Watson (cricketer)|Ryan Watson]] * [[Terence Racionzer]] * [[Ian Peebles]] * [[George Salmond]] * [[Robert Sievwright]] * [[Colin Smith (Scottish cricketer)|Colin Smith]] * [[Douglas Barr (cricketer)|Dougie Barr]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.cricketscotland.com|Cricket Council}} – official site
