page.title: Joe Palooka in the Big Fight

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Joe Palooka in the Big Fight | image = "Joe_Palooka_in_the_Big_Fight"_(1949).jpg | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Cy Endfield]] | producer = [[Hal E. Chester]] | screenplay = [[Stanley Prager]] | narrator = | starring = [[Leon Errol]]
[[Joe Kirkwood Jr]] | music = [[Edward J. Kay]] | cinematography = [[Mack Stengler]] | editing = [[Otho Lovering]]
[[Fred Maguire]] | studio = [[Monogram Pictures]] | distributor = Monogram Pictures | released = 1949 | runtime = 66 mins | country = | language = English | budget = }} '''''Joe Palooka in the Big Fight''''' is a 1949 comedy film directed by Cy Endfield,[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/79800/Joe-Palooka-in-the-Big-Fight/ ''Joe Palooka in the Big Fight''] at [[TCMDB]] based on the comic strip by [[Ham Fisher]].{{cite web|url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/4ce2b6ad9b8eb |title=Joe Palooka in the Big Fight | BFI | BFI |publisher=Explore.bfi.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}} It is an entry in [[Monogram Pictures|Monogram]]'s low-budget, high-grossing ''[[Joe Palooka]]'' series.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/joe-palooka-in-the-big-fight-v97226 |title=Joe Palooka in the Big Fight (1949) - Trailers, Reviews, Synopsis, Showtimes and Cast |publisher=AllMovie |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}} ==Plot== Joe is framed by gamblers who hope to fix the outcome of an upcoming boxing match. When Joe manages to clear his name, the gamblers frame the scrupulously honest boxer with murder. On the run from the law, Joe is forced to turn gumshoe and solve the murder himself—and he'd better hurry if he's going to get to the Big Fight on time. ==Cast== *Knobby - [[Leon Errol]] *Joe Palooka - [[Joe Kirkwood, Jr.]] *Tom Conway - [[David Bruce (actor)|David Bruce]] *Maxine Harlan - [[Lina Romay (singer)|Lina Romay]] *Louie - [[George O'Hanlon]] *Anne Howe - [[Virginia Welles]] *Grady - [[Greg McClure]] *Dr. Benson - [[Taylor Holmes]] *Mike - [[Ian MacDonald (actor)|Ian Macdonald]] *Talmadge - [[Lou Lubin]] *Pee Wee - [[Bert Conway]] *Lt. Muldoon - [[Lyle Talbot]] *Fight Secretary - [[Benny Baker]] *Canvas - [[Eddie Gribbon]] *Scranton - [[Jack Roper]] *Wardrobe Woman - Frances Osborne *Commissioner L.R. Harris - [[Harry Hayden]] *Detective Williams - [[Frank Fenton (actor)|Frank Fenton]] *Contest Announcer - [[George Fisher (actor)|George Fisher]] *Frank T. Macy, Fight Manager - [[Ned Glass]] *Fight Promoter - [[Dick Elliott]] *First Referee - [[John Indrisano]] *Romero's Manager - [[Harry Tyler (actor)|Harry Tyler]] *Mr. Howe - [[Paul Maxey]] *Detective Burns - [[Dewey Robinson]] ==Critical reception== ''[[TV Guide]]'' noted a "better-than-average "Joe Palooka" film...Making the most of realistic dialog, director Cyril Endfield moves the film along at a nice pace while holding together a number of plot lines. Surprisingly, there isn't much boxing footage in this one.{{cite web|url=http://movies.tvguide.com/joe-palooka-in-the-big-fight/review/102783 |title=Joe Palooka In The Big Fight Review |publisher=Movies.tvguide.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0041524/ ''Joe Palooka in the Big Fight''] at [[IMDB]] {{Cy Endfield}} [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:1940s sports films]] [[Category:1949 films]] [[Category:Boxing films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films based on American comics]] [[Category:Films directed by Cy Endfield]] {{sport-film-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | fullname = Juan Ramón Loubriel Stadium | nickname = JRL
La Islandera | image = Estadio Juan Ramón Loubriel Noche.jpg | caption = Front view of the stadium | address = Route 2, intersection with Route 5 | location = [[Cerro Gordo (Bayamón)|Cerro Gordo]], [[Bayamón, Puerto Rico]] | coordinates = {{Coord|18.393425|-66.15085|type:landmark|name=Juan Ramón Loubriel|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1972 | built = 1973 | opened = 1974 | renovated = 2003, 2012 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Municipio de Bayamón | operator = Municipio de Bayamón | surface = Grass | construction_cost = Unknown | architect = Thomas Marvel{{cite web|title=Juan Ramón Loubriel: deportista y educador|url=http://dialogoupr.com/juan-ramon-loubriel-deportista-y-educador/ |publisher=DialogoUPR.com|accessdate=November 5, 2016}} | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Puerto Rico national football team|Puerto Rico men's national football team]]
[[Puerto Rico women's national football team]]
[[Vaqueros de Bayamón (baseball)|Vaqueros de Bayamón]] ([[Liga de Béisbol Profesional Roberto Clemente|PRBL]]) (1974–2003)
[[Cangrejeros de Santurce (baseball)|Cangrejeros de Santurce]] (PRBL) (late 80s)
[[Puerto Rico Islanders]] ([[North American Soccer League|NASL]]) (2004–2012)
[[Puerto Rico FC]] (NASL) (2016–present) | seating_capacity = 22,000 | dimensions = 105 × 68 m | record_attendance = 12,993 – [[Puerto Rico Islanders]] vs. [[LA Galaxy]]
(August 4, 2010) }} '''Juan Ramón Loubriel Stadium''' (Spanish: ''Estadio Juan Ramón Loubriel'') is a [[soccer-specific stadium]] located in [[Bayamón, Puerto Rico]]. It is best known as the former home of the [[Puerto Rico Islanders]] of the [[North American Soccer League]] and current home of the [[Puerto Rico FC]] of the [[North American Soccer League]]. The stadium can seat up to 22,000 people. It has easy access the metro station known as "Deportivo Station." ==History== Created in 1973 as a [[baseball]] stadium with a capacity of 12,500, it was home to the [[Vaqueros de Bayamón (baseball)|Vaqueros de Bayamón]] up until 2003 when the team became defunct. ===La Meca of Puerto Rican Football=== In 2003 with the Vaqueros folding, the stadium seemed doomed to be relegated to a youth stadium or to demolition, but late that same year the stadium was reborn and was to be home for another professional club. However, this time it would be as an [[association football]] stadium. It had been chosen by the [[Puerto Rico Islanders]] as their new home. Its "''L''" shaped stands were not suited for the sport and it originally had an awkward feel to it since the stand behind the goal angles away from the pitch. This has led most of the fans to prefer to sit in the part of the stands that run parallel to the pitch. Over the period that it has hosted the sport of [[soccer]] it has created an atmosphere that is unique to the stadium and the Islanders. It has played host to the resurgence of association football in Puerto Rico and has been given the nickname "La Meca" because it has been a key player in the sport's rise to popularity in the island.{{cite web|url=http://www.sanjuancapital.com/noticiasread.asp?r=53866ISB4A |title=Reconocen pioneros Islanders |publisher=Municipality of San Juan |language=Spanish |date=2006-06-19 |accessdate=2009-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930020953/http://www.sanjuancapital.com/noticiasread.asp?r=53866ISB4A |archivedate=September 30, 2007 }} It is also called "JRL" by fans as an abbreviation of its official name. Another name that has been used for the stadium is "La Islandera" since it was the home of the Islanders.{{cite web| url=http://www.prislandersfc.com/index/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=83&Itemid=68| title=Estadio Juan Ramón Loubriel - Bayamón, Puerto Rico | publisher=Puerto Rico Islanders| language=Spanish| date=2008-08-23| accessdate=2008-08-26}} It was home to [[Bayamon FC]], a professional football team in the [[Puerto Rico Soccer League]] now playing in the [[Bayamon Soccer Complex]], And Sevilla Bayamon FC, now called [[Sevilla FC Puerto Rico|Sevilla-FC Juncos]], they moved to [[Juncos, Puerto Rico|Juncos]]. It has also played host to the [[CFU Club Championship]] Group C in 2006, where the Islanders played but lost to [[Trinidad and Tobago]], [[W Connection]] 0-1 and the [[Puerto Rico MLS-USL Challenge]] in 2007, and two [[2010 World Cup]] qualifying matches against the [[Dominican Republic national football team|Dominican Republic]] and [[Honduras national football team|Honduras]]. ====Renovation in 2012==== The renovations to the stadium have been made to upgrade a stadium created for baseball to be soccer-specific. The stadium will also have new dressing rooms and bathrooms and the replacement of some seating. There will also be some temporary bleachers until the addition for new seating is completed later. Lighting has also been adjusted to be more uniform across the field.{{cite web|url=http://www.insidemnsoccer.com/2012/07/26/first-stage-of-renovations-for-juan-ramon-loubriel-stadium-close-to-complete/|title=First Stage of Renovations for Juan Ramon Loubriel Stadium Close to Complete|publisher=IM Soccer News|date=July 26, 2012|accessdate=November 18, 2017}} The remodeling of the stadium will be done in several stages, with a total cost of $7 million.{{cite web| url=http://thesportpress.com/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=1647:remodelaci%C3%B3n-millonaria-al-juan-ram%C3%B3n-loubriel&Itemid=123| title=Remodelacion millonaria - Bayamón, Puerto Rico | publisher=The sport press| language=Spanish| date=2012-02-04| accessdate=2012-02-07}} [[File:Panoramic Juan Ramón Loubriel Stadium.jpg|400px|thumb|left|A view of the stadium in 2012 after the first phase of renovation.]] ===A new team, a new home (2015-2017)=== In 2015, it was announced home to [[Puerto Rico FC]] of the [[North American Soccer League]]. The team will begin play in the [[2016 North American Soccer League season]] of Fall season. ===Hurricane damage to the stadium (2017)=== On September 22, 2017, the stadium was severely damaged by [[Hurricane Maria]], which led to cancellations of the games and forcing [[Puerto Rico FC]] to play the next same matches in neutral venues, leaving the stadium with complete uncertainty for future matches until fixes are made. ==Events== The first boxing bout between [[Alfredo Escalera]] and [[Alexis Argüello]] dubbed [[The Bloody Battle of Bayamon]], took place at the stadium on January 28, 1978. In September 26, 1992 the heavy metal band Iron Maiden played on their Fear of the Dark Tour. First time Iron Maiden visit Puerto Rico. The popstar [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] performed a sold out concert at the stadium on October 26, 1993 during [[The Girlie Show World Tour]]. The rock band [[Aerosmith]] performed in here on January 28, 1994 during their [[Get a Grip Tour]]. ==References== {{Portal|Association football|Puerto Rico}} {{commons}} {{Reflist}} {{Puerto Rico Islanders}} {{NASL Stadiums}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Juan Ramon Loubriel Stadium}} [[Category:Bayamón FC]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Bayamón, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Defunct baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Football venues in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:North American Soccer League stadiums]] [[Category:Puerto Rico Islanders]] [[Category:Puerto Rico FC]] [[Category:Defunct National Premier Soccer League stadiums]] [[Category:1974 establishments in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1974]] [[Category:Sports venues in Puerto Rico]]

{{Infobox person | name = Larry Stevenson | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Richard Lawrence Stevenson | birth_date = December 22, 1930 | birth_place = Los Angeles, California | death_date = {{death date and age|2012|3|25|1930|12|22|df=y|}} | death_place = [[Santa Monica, California]] | nationality = American | occupation = Inventor | known_for = Skateboard [[kicktail]] | alma_mater = [[Santa Monica College]] | years_active = | spouse = | awards = | signature = }} '''Richard Lawrence "Larry" Stevenson''' (December 22, 1930 – March 25, 2012) was the inventor of the [[kicktail]], the bent-upwards end of a [[skateboard]], which made most of today's [[skateboarding trick]]s possible and essentially revolutionized the sport.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/action/skateboarding/story/_/id/7740600/skateboard-kicktail-innovator-larry-stevenson-dies-81 |title=Skateboard kicktail innovator, Larry Stevenson, dies at 81 - ESPN |publisher=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-27}}</ref>
==Early life== Stevenson was born in 1930 in [[Los Angeles, California]];<ref>{{cite news|last1=Slotnik|first1=Daniel E.|title=Larry Stevenson, Innovative Skateboard Designer, Is Dead at 81|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/27/sports/larry-stevenson-skateboard-designer-dies-at-81.html|accessdate=17 October 2017|work=New York Times}}</ref> his mother was Inez Kiem and his father was Leonard Stevenson. After high school Larry Stevenson joined the U.S. Navy as a fighter mechanic. He served for two years in the [[Korean War]].
After that, he went on to [[Santa Monica College]] in California and became a swimmer. He played water polo and swam for Coach John Josephs. Stevenson won the all American award for fastest time for the breast stroke. The record was only recently{{When|date=November 2010}} broken, and he was given a lifetime allowance into any Santa Monica College event, if he wished to attend. After SMC, Stevenson went to USC, on a swimming scholarship, where he majored in business.
During the middle to late part of the 1950s, Stevenson became a Venice Beach lifeguard for the city of Los Angeles. While sitting watching surfers he noticed they would skate on crude skateboards back in the parking lots at the beach. This was true especially when there was no surf. Stevenson, while visiting Hawaii en route to Korea, during the war noticed a great surfing beach called "Makaha". All those years later he remembered how much he liked the beach in Hawaii, but he also loved the name Makaha.
After a short period of time, Stevenson started MAKAHA skateboards. He is credited with being the man who made the first high-quality skateboard. He patented the double kicktail in 1969, had the first skate team in 1963, and held the first skateboard contest in 1963.<ref name="Rompella2007">{{cite book|last=Rompella|first=Natalie|title=Famous firsts: the trendsetters, groundbreakers & risk-takers who got America moving!|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bc-_uWnoZWwC&pg=PA30|accessdate=21 October 2010|year=2007|publisher=Lobster Press|isbn=978-1-897073-55-1|page=30}}</ref> Stevenson also published ''Surfguide'' magazine during the 1960s, and [[Poweredge Magazine|Poweredge]] skateboarding magazine during the 1980s and 1990s. He was involved with Makaha and ''Poweredge''; both have been reborn with new editors.
==Death== Stevenson died on March 25, 2012 from complications of pneumonia due to Parkinson's disease in his Santa Monica home.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.makahaskateboards.com/ Makaha Skateboards] - Larry Stevenson history & information
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stevenson, Larry}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:American inventors]] [[Category:Sports inventors and innovators]] [[Category:Skateboarding equipment]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]]

{{about||the English cricketer|Lee Cooper (cricketer)|the American blues musician|Lee Cooper (guitarist)}} {{Infobox company |name = Lee Cooper |logo = Logo Lee Cooper.jpg |type = Subsidiary |genre = |fate = |predecessor = |successor = |foundation = 1908 (as M. Cooper Overalls) |founder = Morris Cooper |defunct = |location_city = |location_country = |location = [[London]], [[England]],
[[Great Britain]] |locations = |area_served = |key_people = Andy Dunkley (CEO) |industry = Clothing |products = |production = |services = |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |aum = |assets = |equity = |owner = |num_employees = |parent = [[Iconix Brand Group|Iconix Brand Group Inc.]] |caption = ''Your best profile'' |homepage = {{URL|http://www.leecooper.com}} |footnotes = |intl = }} '''Lee Cooper Brand''' is an English [[clothing]] company, operating worldwide, that licenses the sale of many '''Lee Cooper'''-branded items, including [[denim]] [[jeans]]. The head office is located in [[London]], [[England]]. The company originally produced workwear for export, and began to specialise in denim jackets and trousers in the 1930s. In 2013, [[Iconix Brand Group]] acquired Lee Cooper from [[Sun Capital Partners]].[http://www.altassets.net/private-equity-news/by-news-type/deal-news/sun-european-partners-sells-lee-cooper-for-72m.html Sun European Partners sells Lee Cooper for $72m] ==History== ===Early years=== The brand that eventually became Lee Cooper was established in 1908 by Morris Cooper and a friend, Louis Maister, after they arrived in London from their hometown in [[Lithuania]] (then part of the [[Russian Empire]]), having previously spent some time in [[South Africa]]. Operating under the name M. Cooper (Overalls) Ltd., from premises on Middlesex Street in London's [[East End]], they began production of workwear, having identified a market for it in South Africa.{{cite web|url=http://www.leecooper.com/history1.php |title=Lee Cooper |publisher=Leecooper.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-18}} During the years of the [[First World War]], M. Cooper (Overalls), which by then employed over 600 people, halted production of workwear and began making uniforms, kit bags and rucksacks for the [[British Army]]. In 1937, a new factory dedicated to the manufacture of denim was opened in Stratford, with the business reporting a profit of £1,000 by year end.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article5132618.ece |title=Times Harold Cooper obituary |publisher=Timesonline.com |date= 2008-11-12|accessdate=2010-08-18 | location=London}} The outbreak of the [[Second World War]] in 1939 led Morris Cooper to split the business into two: one arm continued making workwear, while the other concentrated on producing military uniforms, battle fatigues and flight overalls. M. Cooper (Overalls) eventually became one of the biggest suppliers to [[Her Majesty's Armed Forces]].{{cite web|url=http://www.leecooper.com/history3.php |title=Lee Cooper |publisher=Leecooper.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-18}} ===Post-war=== Morris Cooper died in 1940 and his son, Harold Cooper, took over the business upon his return from active service in the [[Royal Air Force|RAF]]. He set about modernising the company and building on its wartime success, switching focus to casual wear and denim production, and taking advantage of the introduction of clothes rationing to increase competitiveness.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article5132618.ece |title=Times Harold Cooper obituary |publisher=Timesonline.com |date= 2008-11-12|accessdate=2010-08-18 | location=London}} As part of a re-branding strategy, the company was rechristened, with Harold adding a version of his wife's family name, Leigh, to his own to create "Lee Cooper".{{cite web|url=http://www.leecooper.com/history4.php |title=Lee Cooper |publisher=Leecooper.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-18}} Lee Cooper jeans were adopted by the youth counterculture of the 1950s and 1960s and Harold capitalised on this association by sponsoring a [[The Rolling Stones|Rolling Stones]] tour and working with [[Serge Gainsbourg]] and [[Jane Birkin]]. The company caused a degree of moral outrage in 1953 by introducing the zip-front to women's jeans{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/views/obituaries/2008/11/13/harold-cooper-64375-22245380/ |title=Liverpool Daily Post Harold Cooper obituary |publisher=Liverpooldailypost.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-08-18}} and commissioned a series of bold publicity campaigns, some of them incorporating fictitious designers such as the Italian 'Alfredo Angelous' in order to appeal to subcultures such as the [[Mod (subculture)|Mods]], who favoured continental style.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article5132618.ece |title=Times Harold Cooper obituary |publisher=Timesonline.com |date= 2008-11-12|accessdate=2010-08-18 | location=London}} The late 1970s saw expansion of production, with the company opening factories in Ireland, France and Tunisia and by the mid 1980s these facilities were producing between 40,000 and 45,000 garments per week. During this time, annual turnover grew to more than £100 million. Lee Cooper was also one of the main pitchside sponsors at [[UEFA Euro 1984|the 1984 European Championships]] in France. In 1989, the Cooper family sold their majority stake in the business and since then Lee Cooper has become a 'lifestyle' brand, operating in more than seventy markets across the world. In 2008, the company celebrated its [[centenary]].{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article5132618.ece |title=Times Harold Cooper obituary |publisher=Timesonline.com |date= 2008-11-12|accessdate=2010-08-18 | location=London}} ==See also== *[[Lee Jeans]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.leecooper.com/ Lee Cooper Homepage] {{Iconix Brand Group}} [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1908]] [[Category:Jeans by brand]] [[Category:Clothing companies of England]] [[Category:Companies based in the City of London]] [[Category:1908 establishments in England]] [[Category:English brands]] [[Category:Companies established in 1908]] [[Category:Clothing companies of England]] [[Category:Iconix Brand Group]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]]

Benfica]] | tenants = [[S.L. Benfica (basketball)|Basketball]]
[[S.L. Benfica (futsal)|Futsal]]
[[S.L. Benfica (roller hockey)|Roller Hockey]] | embedded = | website = [https://www.slbenfica.pt/en-us/espacos/complexo-desportivo/ slbenfica.pt] | publictransit = Alto dos Moinhos and Colégio Militar/Luz
[[Lisbon Metro]] Blue Line }} The '''Pavilhão da Luz Nº 1''', known as '''Pavilhão Fidelidade''' for sponsorship reasons, is the main [[indoor arena|arena]] of Portuguese multi-sport club [[S.L. Benfica]]. It has a capacity of 2,400 seats and it is mainly used by the [[S.L. Benfica (basketball)|basketball]], [[S.L. Benfica (futsal)|futsal]] and [[S.L. Benfica (roller hockey)|roller hockey]] departments of the club. Built at the same time as the new [[Estádio da Luz]], it was designed from the start to replace the 37-year old Pavilhão da Luz, which was torn down in March 2003.{{cite news|title=Seara Cardoso abre "caixinha" da nova Luz|trans-title=Seara Cardoso opens "little box" of the new Luz|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/liga-nos/benfica/detalhe/seara-cardoso-abre-caixinha-da-nova-luz.html|access-date=21 March 2016|work=Record.pt|date=4 December 2002|language=Portuguese}}{{cite news|title=Últimas emoções no Pavilhão da Luz|trans-title=Last thrills in Pavilhão da Luz|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/modalidades/hoquei-em-patins/detalhe/ultimas-emocoes-no-pavilhao-da-luz.html|access-date=21 March 2016|work=Record|date=15 March 2003|language=Portuguese}} Opened on 28 February 2004, during the celebrations of the club centenary, its first game opposed the basketball section against [[Ovarense Basquetebol|Ovarense]].{{cite news|title=A catedral das modalidades|trans-title=The cathedral of sports|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/liga-nos/benfica/detalhe/a-catedral-das-modalidades.html|access-date=21 March 2016|work=Record|date=28 February 2004|language=Portuguese}} Its features include a [[NBA]]-style scoreboard, and other standard amenities like safety nets behind the goals, [[press box]]es, five [[changing room|locker rooms]], bars, medical offices and accommodation to handicapped fans. Eight months after its opening, Benfica sold the arena [[naming rights]] to [[Banif Financial Group|Açoreana Seguros]] for a fee rumoured to be close to €1 million.{{cite news|title=Açoreana Seguros dá nome ao pavilhão|trans-title=Açoreana Seguros gets naming rights|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/liga-nos/benfica/detalhe/acoreana-seguros-da-nome-ao-pavilhao.html|access-date=21 March 2016|work=Record|date=7 October 2004|language=Portuguese}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|https://www.slbenfica.pt/en-us/espacos/complexo-desportivo/}} * [https://www.zerozero.pt/estadio.php?id=1808 Pavilhão Fidelidade] at zerozero {{pt icon}} {{S.L. Benfica}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pavilhao da Luz N 1}} [[Category:S.L. Benfica]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Portugal]] [[Category:Sports venues in Lisbon]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2004]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Portugal]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{For|the pressurized garment worn by high-altitude pilots and astronauts|Pressure suit}} {{For|the positive-pressure mask or hood|Powered air-purifying respirator}} {{For|unpressurized protective garments|Hazmat suit}} [[File:Positive-pressure biosafety suit.jpg|thumb|220px|right|A [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] laboratorian dons an older-model PPPS before entering a Maximum Containment lab, or “suit lab”.]] '''Positive pressure personnel suits''' ('''PPPS''') — or '''positive pressure protective suits''', informally known as "'''space suits'''", "'''moon suits'''", "'''blue suits'''", etc. — are highly specialized, totally encapsulating, industrial protection garments worn only within special [[biocontainment]] or maximum containment ([[Biosafety level|BSL-4]]) laboratory facilities. These facilities research [[Biological agents|dangerous pathogens]] which are highly infectious and may have no treatments or vaccines available. These facilities also feature other special equipment and procedures such as [[airlock]] entry, quick-drench disinfectant showers, special waste disposal systems, and shower exits. The PPPS is a sophisticated variety of [[personal protective equipment]] (PPE), a type of [[hazmat suit]], which is air-tight and designed for [[positive pressure]] to prevent contamination to the wearer even if the suit becomes damaged. BSL-4 cabinets and "Suit Laboratories" have special engineering and design features to prevent hazardous microorganisms from being disseminated into the outside environment. These [[biosafety suites]], where PPPSs are used, are suites of laboratory rooms which are essentially equivalent to large Class III [[biosafety cabinet]]s in which the interiors of the PPPSs serve as the "outside" environment for workers. Examples include the biocontainment suites at the [[U.S. Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases]] (USAMRIID) at [[Fort Detrick, Maryland]] and the [[Maximum Containment Facility]] (MCF) of the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. ==Operation== [[File:NIAID Integrated Research Facility - Positive Pressure Personnel Suit Inspection.jpg|thumb|Regular inspection of PPPS to locate any punctures or leaks{{cite web|last1=Seligson|first1=Susan|title=Video Offers Glimpse of Biosafety Level 4 Lab Science webcast "threads the NEIDL"|url=http://www.bu.edu/today/2013/video-offers-glimpse-of-biosafety-level-4-lab/|website=BU Today|accessdate=5 December 2014|date=7 March 2013}}]] Fresh, filtered air is typically supplied to the interior of a PPPS via overhead tubing. In addition to the physical barrier provided, the positive pressurization offers additional protection in the event of exposure through a defect or puncture in the suit, for if the suit’s integrity is compromised, air will be forced out instead of being sucked in. Extensive training with the PPPS is required to safely pursue research in a PPPS within a biosafety facility. In 1987, USAMRIID scientist Joel Dalrymple described the subjective experience of working in a PPPS and "his solemn respect for working in the hot suits" to a journalist:
"I don't want anyone to prep my suit," he says. "It is like packing your own parachute." Indeed, it is no picnic to do experiments weighted down with all that gear and paraphernalia. The air hisses so loudly you have to crimp the air supply to talk to your lab partner. The plastic eyeshield reflects the lightbulbs in the ceiling. Heat builds up. Fatigue sets in. You can't scratch or go to the bathroom. And all the time, there is the danger that you will slip and puncture your suit and infect yourself. After working in the hot suite, everyone showers and checks the suit, just to make sure that no tiny punctures turn up. "It's just instinct," says Dalrymple. "You come out, pull off your glove, blow it up and hold it. You've been working with needles all day. It is refreshing to see a glove that remains inflated."McDermott, Jeanne (1987), ''The Killing Winds: The Menace of Biological Warfare''; [[New York City|New York]]; [[Arbor House]], pp 220-221.
{{expand section|date=December 2011}} ==History== In the late 1970s, [[ILC Dover]], LP, developed a special garment, the [[Demilitarization Protective Ensemble]] (DPE), to fulfill the [[U.S. Army]]’s need for an off-the-shelf, positive pressure, totally encapsulating suit for use by maintenance personnel at a [[chemical weapon]]s site. The DPE was delivered to the Army in 1979 and is still currently in daily use, with over 700 recorded entries into a "hot" environment and a perfect safety record. From the technology used in production of the DPE, ILC developed a PPPS to be used for commercial applications. Delta Protection, a subsidiary of French company Bacou-Dalloz, designed a [[Michelin Man]]-inspired suit in 2003, known in the United States at that time as French BSL 4 Suit.{{cite news|last1=Masibay|first1=Kimberly|title=A Chic French Import Attracts U.S. Attention|url=http://www.popsci.com/scitech/article/2003-05/hot-zone-couture|accessdate=5 December 2014|work=Popular Science|date=27 May 2003}} In July 2007, the CDC purchased 30 Delta Protection suits to be used in BSL-4,{{cite web|title=84 -- BSL-4 Protective Suit: Solicitation Number: Reference-Number-00HCVHDB-2007-45398|url=https://www.fbo.gov/index?s=opportunity&mode=form&id=3f464234e94bae197063f2477caa0c8e&tab=core&_cview=0|website=CDC|accessdate=5 December 2014}} and called them "orange suits".{{cite web|title=PHIL # 10727|url=http://phil.cdc.gov/phil/details.asp?pid=10727|website=CDC|accessdate=5 December 2014}}{{cite web|title=PHIL # 10724|url=http://phil.cdc.gov/phil/details.asp?pid=10724|website=CDC|accessdate=5 December 2014}} On August 20, 2007, Bacou-Dalloz became [[Sperian Protection]].{{cite web|title=Stanley Personal Protection History|url=https://stanleypersonalprotection.com/History|website=Stanley|accessdate=5 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209164200/https://stanleypersonalprotection.com/History#|archive-date=2014-12-09|dead-url=yes|df=}} The same suit design became part of Sperian Protection ventilated suits ("White Suits").{{cite web|title=Solutions to Protect People Against Particles|url=http://www.nanosafe.org/home/liblocal/docs/2008_Oral%20presentations/O5-5_Sperian%20Protection.pdf|website=NanoSafe|accessdate=5 December 2014|date=2008}} On September 15, 2010, Sperian Protection became part of [[Honeywell]].{{cite web|title=Sperian Protection, Historical Player|url=http://www.sperian.com/The_Group/History.aspx|website=Sperian Protection|accessdate=5 December 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110211231854/http://www.sperian.com/The_Group/History.aspx|archivedate=11 February 2011}} The product is now called Honeywell BSL 4 suits.{{cite web|title=Product Family BSL 4|url=http://www.honeywellsafety.com/Products/Protective_Clothing/BSL_4.aspx?site=/americas|website=Honeywell|accessdate=5 December 2014}} The Chemturion series is a series of multi-use, totally encapsulating PPPSs, currently used by [[Health Canada|Public Health Canada]], [[Boston University]], [[AI Signal Research]], USAMRIID, the CDC, and many industrial companies such as [[DuPont]], [[Dow Chemical Company|Dow]], and [[Georgia Pacific]].U.S. Army Chemical Materials Agency, [http://www.cma.army.mil/fndocumentviewer.aspx?docid=003676566 Suiting up for Safety, Fact Sheet] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923204937/http://www.cma.army.mil/fndocumentviewer.aspx?docid=003676566 |date=2015-09-23 }}. Retrieved on 2011-02-11. {{expand section|date=December 2011}} ==Examples== *The U.S. Army's [[Demilitarization Protective Ensemble]] *The [[ILC Dover#Protective suits|ILC Dover Chemturion]] "Blue Suit" *The Delta Protection "Orange Suit" *The [[Sperian Protection]]{{dead link|date=March 2017}} "White Suit"Sperian Protection is now part of [[Honeywell]]; [http://www.sperian.com/The_Group/History.aspx Sperian Group History] File:Biosafety level 4 hazmat suit.jpg|A [[BSL-4]] laboratorian working in an ILC Dover Chemturion "Blue Suit". File:Positive-pressure suit (orange suit).jpg|[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] microbiologists in Delta Protection "Orange Suits" File:NIAID Integrated Research Facility - Positive Pressure Personnel Suit.jpg|Laboratorians working in Sperian Protection "White Suit" at [[NIAID]] BSL-4 lab File:Performing maintenance work in DPE suits at NECDF.jpg|Maintenance workers in [[Demilitarization Protective Ensemble|DPE suit]]s at the [[Newport Chemical Agent Disposal Facility]]. ==In fiction and film== {{Unreferenced section|date=August 2017}} PPPSs — along with many less elaborate types of hazmat suit — have long been a staple of the [[science fiction]] and [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]] genres, where they are used to accentuate the drama of [[biohazard]] scenarios. Common dramatic (and generally unrealistic) situations involve a suit failure leading to rapid death in films such as ''[[Outbreak (film)|Outbreak]]'' (1995). The wearing of a PPPS can underscore the villainy and "otherness" of movie bad guys as in ''[[E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial]]'' (1982). A recent, more sedate, example of PPPSs in a film is the [[Steven Soderbergh]] movie ''[[Contagion (film)|Contagion]]'' (2011). In the ''[[Mass Effect (video game)|Mass Effect]]'' series of [[Video game|video games]], several types of aliens use variants of PPPSs, most notably the character Tali, who suffers from a compromised [[immune system]]. In [[Jean Giraud|Moebius]]'s comic ''Edena'', the residents of the Nest City wear similar suits at all times to protect themselves from diseases, as do the denizens of Javecek in Carla Speed McNeill's comic ''[[Finder (comics)|Finder]].''{{Cite book|title=Edena|last=Giraud|first=Jean|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}{{Cite book|title=Finder: Third World|last=McNeill|first=Carla|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}} In Bethesda's ''[[Fallout (series)|Fallout]]'' games'','' the Hazmat Suit is an armor item which can be equipped on a character to prevent [[radiation]] damage. Frank Herbert's novel ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'' also features a group of people who wear elaborate gear known as "stillsuits"; however, these are built to maximize water retention in a desert environment and not as a barrier against [[Pathogen|pathogens]] or chemicals.{{Cite book|title=Dune|last=Herbert|first=Frank|publisher=Ace Books|year=1965|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{U.S. biological defense}} [[Category:Safety clothing]] [[Category:Protective gear]] [[Category:Environmental suits]] [[Category:One-piece suits]]

{{Infobox stadium |stadium_name = Prince George's Stadium |nickname = |image = PGStadiumBowie.jpg |image_size = 200px |location = 4101 Crain Highway
Bowie, MD 20716 |coordinates = {{coord|38|56|44|N|76|42|33|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |broke_ground = October 17, 1993{{cite web |title=Construction under way for home of baseball's AA Bowie Baysox|first=Athena|last=Schaffer|url=http://business.highbeam.com/53/article-1G1-14532488/construction-under-way-home-baseball-aa-bowie-baysox|work=Amusement Business|date=October 18, 1993|accessdate=September 24, 2011}} |opened = June 16, 1994 |closed = |demolished = |owner = [[Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission]] |operator = [[Bowie Baysox]]/[[Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission]] |surface = Natural Grass |construction_cost = US$10 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|10000000|1994}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) |architect = [[Tetra Tech|The Design Exchange]]{{cite news |title=Queen of Diamonds|first=Terry|last=Conway|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/philadelphia/stories/1999/06/07/smallb1.html?page=all|newspaper=[[American City Business Journals|Philadelphia Business Journal]]|date=June 7, 1999|accessdate=August 27, 2013}} |project_manager = [[Opening Day Partners]]{{cite web |title=Stadium Design and Construction|url=http://openingdaypartners.com/design.cfm|publisher=Opening Day Partners|accessdate=June 5, 2014}} |general_contractor = Sigal Construction Corp.{{cite news |title=Weather Thwarts Baysox; New Stadium Unlikely To Open on Schedule|first=David|last=Montgomery|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/72228964.html?dids=72228964:72228964&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Mar+03%2C+1994&author=David+Montgomery&pub=The+Washington+Post+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Weather+Thwarts+Baysox%3B+New+Stadium+Unlikely+To+Open+on+Schedule&pqatl=google|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=March 3, 1994|accessdate=September 17, 2011}} |former_names = |tenants = [[Bowie Baysox]] ([[Eastern League (baseball)|EL]]) (1994–present)
[[D.C. Forward]] ([[Pro Cricket|PC]]) (2004) |seating_capacity = 10,000{{cite web|url=http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?ymd=20090311&content_id=40995586&sid=t418&vkey=team1|title=Bowie Baysox Baysox/Stadium Info|work=[[Minor League Baseball]]|accessdate=4 May 2015}} |dimensions = Left Field: {{convert|309|ft|m}}
Center Field: {{convert|405|ft|m}}
Right Field: {{convert|309|ft|m}} }} '''Prince George's Stadium''' is a multipurpose sports venue located in [[unincorporated area|unincorporated]] [[Prince George's County, Maryland]], near [[Bowie, Maryland|Bowie]],{{cite web |url=https://www.cityofbowie.org/DocumentCenter/View/6847/Bowie-Neighborhoods-Map |title=Bowie Neighborhoods |website=[[Bowie, Maryland|City of Bowie]] |access-date=August 28, 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://www.pgparks.com/Facilities/Facility/Details/Prince-Georges-Stadium-85 |title=Prince George's Stadium |website=Prince George's County Department of Parks and Recreation |access-date=September 2, 2018 |quote=Prince George's Stadium 4101 Northeast Crain Highway Bowie, MD 20715}} primarily used for [[baseball]]. It is home of the [[Baltimore Orioles]]' [[Double-A (baseball)|Double-A]] affiliate in the [[Eastern League (baseball)|Eastern League]], the [[Bowie Baysox]]. The stadium is the result of a cooperative venture between Maryland Baseball Limited Partnership and the [[Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission]], and is built on park property. ==History== The stadium opened June 16, 1994.{{cite news |title=Two Months Late, It's 'Play Ball!' Time in Bowie|first=David|last=Montgomery|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=June 2, 1994}} Its capacity for baseball is listed at 10,000, but when the Double-A All-Star Game was held there in [[2000 in sports|2000]], the attendance was about 14,000. The 2002 [[Major League Lacrosse All-Star Game]] was held at the stadium. While the stadium was being finished, the Baysox played one full season (1993) at Baltimore's [[Memorial Stadium (Baltimore)|Memorial Stadium]] and a few series in 1994 at fields belonging to the [[United States Naval Academy]] in [[Annapolis]], and the [[University of Maryland, College Park]], as well as the minor league stadiums of the [[Frederick Keys]] and [[Wilmington Blue Rocks]].{{cite book |title=The Ultimate Minor League Baseball Road Trip: A Fan's Guide to AAA, AA, A, and Independent League Stadiums|first=Joshua|last=Pahigian|year=2007|publisher=The Lyons Press|isbn=978-1-59921-024-7|page=72}} ==Tenants== Prince George's Stadium is located near the intersection of [[U.S. Route 301 (Maryland)|U.S. Route 301]] and [[U.S. Route 50 in Maryland|U.S. Route 50]]. It has been host to the AA All-Star Game twice, the [[United States Congressional Baseball Game]], the annual [[Allen Iverson]] charity softball game, a lacrosse tournament, the USA Softball team, yard sales, movie nights, concerts, and Halloween activities in addition to its primary function as a baseball park. In addition, the Baysox operate a [[drive-in theater]] in the stadium's left-field parking lot during the Baysox' road trips. Due to its close proximity to several local military bases including [[Fort George G. Meade]] and [[Andrews Air Force Base]], the stadium is also regularly the site of related promotions involving enlisted persons. For example, on June 14, 2007, 5,000 Baysox tickets were distributed to soldiers to celebrate Flag Day with professional wrestler [[Sergeant Slaughter]]. In 1998, the stadium hosted the Bowie Nationals,{{cite news|last1=Baker|first1=Kent|title=Fall league opener draws 1,118, but Kirk 'very encouraged' CEO cites rain, promotion|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1998-09-23/sports/1998266019_1_shawn-gallagher-tike-redman-bowie|accessdate=May 17, 2016|work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|date=September 23, 1998}} a team in the single-season [[Maryland Fall Baseball]] league.{{cite news|last1=Hoffmann|first1=John|title=Keys finish first half on a tear; Fall League to fold|url=http://www.gazette.net/gazette_archive/1999/199926/thurmont/sports/a40700-1.html|accessdate=May 17, 2016|work=[[The Gazette (Maryland)|The Gazette]]|date=June 24, 1999}} In 2004, it served as the home of the [[D.C. Forward]], the [[Pro Cricket]] team for Washington, D.C. ==Appearances== Prince George's Stadium was featured in the January 30, 2007 episode ("Well Digger") of the Discovery Channel series ''[[Dirty Jobs]]'', where host [[Mike Rowe (television host)|Mike Rowe]] performed a variety of jobs.{{cite news |title=Closing Bell, January 30, 2007|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Closing-Bell/2007/01/30/Closing-Bell-January-30-2007.aspx|work=[[Sports Business Daily]]|date=January 30, 2007|accessdate=August 21, 2011|quote=The Double-A Eastern League Bowie Baysox, an Orioles affiliate, will be featured on Discovery Channel's "Dirty Jobs" at 9:00pm ET, as host Mike Rowe will be seen washing uniforms, cleaning shoes and mowing the outfield grass at Prince George's Stadium.}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Prince George's Stadium}} * [http://www.pgparks.com/Things_To_Do/Sports/Prince_George_s_Stadium.htm Prince George's County Department of Parks and Recreation] * [http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?sid=t418&ymd=20090311&content_id=522855&vkey=team1 Bowie Baysox] * [http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2001/Bowie/Bowie.htm Stadium Views – ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Bowie Baysox]]  | years = 1994–current | before = [[Memorial Stadium (Baltimore)]] | after = Current }} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[United States Congressional Baseball Game]] | years = 1995–2004 | before = [[Four Mile Run Park]] | after = [[Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium|RFK Stadium]] }} {{end}} {{Eastern League ballparks}} {{Bowie, Maryland}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Prince George's County, Maryland]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Maryland]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in the United States]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Maryland]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1994]] [[Category:Cricket in Maryland]]

{{Infobox football club | | clubname = Vegpro | image = Sher Karuruti.png | image_size = 100px | caption = Former Karuturi Sports logo | fullname = Vegpro Football Club | nickname = | founded = 1994 | ground = [[Naivasha Stadium]]
[[Naivasha]], [[Kenya]] | capacity = 5,000 | chairman = | mgrtitle = Head coach | manager = {{flagicon|KEN}} [[Michael Nam]] | league = [[FKF Division One]] | season = [[2014 Kenyan National Super League|2014]] | position = [[Kenyan National Super League]],
Zone B, 12th (relegated) | pattern_la1= | pattern_b1=_redstripes | pattern_ra1=| | leftarm1=ff0000 | body1=ffffff | rightarm1=ff0000 | shorts1=000000 | socks1=ffffff| }} '''Vegpro''' is a [[Kenya]]n [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Naivasha]]. They currently compete in the [[Kenyan National Super League]], the second tier of Kenyan football. They play their home games at the [[Naivasha Stadium]]. The club was founded in 1994 as '''Sher Agencies Football Club'''. In 2002 it played in the [[Nationwide League (Kenya)|Nationwide League]] and won promotion to the Premier League with the help of two notable names: Anthony Wekesa and Jacob Abu Omondi who were the force behind their promotion. The club was formerly owned by Sher Karuturi Limited, the largest flower producer in Kenya, a subsidiary of Karuturi Global Limited, an Indian company. The company is a producer of cut roses with an area of over 200 hectares under Greenhouse cultivation and an annual production capacity of around 500 million stems. Until November 2014, the club was known as '''Karuturi Sports Club''', when the club was taken over by a multinational fresh produce, flowers and logistics company known as the VP Group.{{cite web|url=http://www.futaa.com/football/article/former-kpl-side-rebrands |title=Former KPL side rebrands |author=Wilson Mathu |publisher=Futaa.com |date=15 October 2014 |accessdate=25 November 2014}} Vegpro's major rivals are [[Oserian F.C.|Oserian]], with whom they are part of the [[Naivasha derby]]. == References == {{Reflist}} *[http://www.kpl.co.ke/content.aspx?Id=15272 Sher Karuturi] at the [[Kenyan Premier League]] website {{Kenyan National Super League plain}} {{Kenyan Premier League plain}} {{Football in Kenya}} [[Category:Kenyan Premier League clubs]] [[Category:Kenyan National Super League clubs]] [[Category:Football clubs in Kenya]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1994]] [[Category:Sport in Rift Valley Province]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Kenya]] {{Kenya-footyclub-stub}}

{{Culture of Wales}}
'''Welsh Handball''' ({{lang-cy|'''Pêl-Law'''}}) is one of the most ancient [[Sport in Wales#Traditional and native sports|native sports]] of [[Wales]]. It is related to coeval sports such as [[Irish handball]], [[fives]], [[Basque pelota]] and is a possible antecedent of [[American handball]]. The sport has been continually attested since the Middle Ages and its popularity saw it become an important expression of [[Welsh culture]], offering ordinary people opportunities through prize-money, bookkeeping and even player professionalism.
Due to its cultural significance games of Pêl-law were simply referred to as ''Chwarae Pêl'' (playing ball) and it has since been described as ''"Wales’s first national sport"''.<ref>{{cite book|last1= Dicks|first1= Kevin|title= Handball. The Story of Wales’ First National Sport|date=2016|publisher=Y Lolfa|location=Wales|edition=1st|language=English}}</ref>
==Rules and scoring== Pêl-law shares many rules and its methods of scoring with other handball games, as well as [[squash (sport)|squash]] and [[racquetball]]. A hard, leather-cased ball (a [[Spaldeen]] is often used today) is struck with the palm against a front wall. The objective is to keep the ball out of the opponent's reach but inside the bounds of play so that they are unable to return. Points are only awarded for the serving player.
Scores are marked on the front wall using the traditional "box" scoring system, and formal matches are overseen by an official score marker and one referee. Whilst historically the rules varied from village to village, the scoring method remained constant and is still in use today.<ref>{{cite web|title=UK's Only Purpose-built Handball Court|url=http://heritageofwalesnews.blogspot.co.uk/2011/01/uks-only-purpose-built-handball-court.html|website=Heritage of Wales News|publisher=blogspot.co.uk|language=Welsh and English}}</ref>
==History==
===Early development=== Similar games to Pêl-law have been played throughout the world for thousands of years. Handball-like games have originated in several places at different times. [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|Hieroglyph]]s in the temple of [[Osiris]] in Egypt portray priests taking part in a game very similar to handball. The Civilisations of [[South America|South]] and Central America had a [[Mesoamerican ballgame|handball-like game]], which was a large part of [[pre-Columbian]] culture. It is likely that the Welsh game has a similarly ancient origin.
Pêl-law has been attested in the [[Medieval Welsh literature|literature of Wales]] since the Middle Ages, and was mentioned by [[Nennius]] in the ninth century. There is evidence that the game was played at [[Tintern Abbey]] and [[Raglan Castle]] once held a Pêl-law court inside its Great Hall of State.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dicks|first1=Kevin|title=Handball – The Story of Wales’ First National Sport|date=2017|publisher=Y Lolfa|isbn=9781784613761}}</ref>
===Importance to Welsh culture=== By [[Tudor times]], most sports in Wales were banned by order of the [[English Crown]]. Sports were banned for a number of reasons, but in Wales they were particularly seen as a distraction from the practice of [[archery]] as [[English Longbow|Welsh longbowmen]] were integral to the defence of the [[Kingdom of England|kingdom]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.mit.edu/21h.416/www/militarytechnology/longbow.html |accessdate=18 Aug 2013 |title=Engineering the Medieval Achievement - The Longbow |author= Prof. Anne McCants |website=web.mit.edu |publisher=[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]]}}</ref>
The banned sports were also seen as encouraging gambling, violence and debauchery with only Christmas (and later Easter) seeing the ban relaxed. As sports enjoyed by the English nobility (such as [[jousting]], [[bear-baiting]] and [[cock-fighting]]) continued with no such restrictions, the outlawed sports came to be seen as an expression of protest against the landowning class. This social context was exacerbated as authorities continued to characterise pêl-law games as havens of mob behavior, sedition and ultimately revolt.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Trueman|first1=CN|title=Tudor Sports And Pastimes|url=http://www.historylearningsite.co.uk/tudor-england/tudor-sports-and-pastimes/|website=The History Learning Site|accessdate=17 Mar 2015}}</ref>
As the Tudor period continued, [[Laws in Wales Acts 1535 and 1542|laws specific to Wales]] were introduced which removed historic Welsh institutions and barred Welsh people (or English people with Welsh connections) from positions of authority. As such, the surviving Welsh folk-pursuits gained a unique cultural significance to ordinary people. By the fifteenth century pêl-law had great enough social importance and popularity that the contemporary [[bard]] [[Guto'r Glyn]] could allude to it in a [[cywydd]] simply entitled ''Y Bêl'' ({{lang-en|The Ball}}).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lloyd|first1=Howard|title=The Transactions of the Honourable Society of Cymmrodorian|date=18 February 1960|publisher=Honourable Society of Cymmrodorion|pages=97–108}}</ref>
===National sport=== The game was initially played against the side of stone buildings like churches, and the sport's popularity among the Welsh populous drew the ire of both Anglican and Non-conformist leaders, with one Welsh Methodist preacher telling his congregations that handball was among the things which were “taking the country to eternal woe”.
{{quote box|
''Who Ever hear on a Sonday,''
''Will Practis Playing At Ball,''
''it May Be before Monday,''
''The Devil Will Have you All.''
|source=Early evidence of the strained relationship between Pêl-law and community leaders. inscribed onto St Marys Church in [[Llanvair Discoed]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dicks|first1=Kevin|title=Handball – The Story of Wales’ First National Sport|date=2017|publisher=Y Lolfa|isbn=9781784613761}}</ref>|align=right|width=40%}}
The eighteenth century saw the construction of the first purpose built courts. The new open-backed courts were often built by the owners of public houses to attract trade and the new venues enabled Pêl-law an unprecedented popularity as a spectator sport. However, the new crowds drew more complaints from landowners, who would often refer to the games as '[[Eton fives|fives]]' a very similar game played by English grammar schools. In 1744 a Joanna Lond of Swansea was accused of: ''"maintaining a certain gaming house for a certain unlawful game called fives"'' and a letter written in 1817, states the author’s objection to the transformation of the courtyard of the church at [[Llandaff]] into a ''"Fives court"'', with games interrupting services. It is likely that such instances actually helped the game maintain a distinct attraction. With Welsh language terminology, an archaic scoring system and distinct working-class culture, any vilification by the [[Anglican church]] or local authority appear to have only added to the sport's unique appeal. This era also saw Pêl-law become popular in the west of England.
[[File:Brecknock against all Britain! Brecon Castle Fives Court 1786.jpg|thumbnail|left|''Brecknock against all Britain! Brecon Castle Fives Court'' A Pêl-law challenge for prize money by two local champions referring to the game by the English name of ''Fives'' (1786)]]
The late nineteenth century also saw a great number of workers move to Wales and it seems the increasing population enjoyed the sport. [[Irish handball]] was a related working-class sport and it is understood that Irish migrants played the Welsh game, with the construction of the Nelson court in the 1860s possibly built with Irish railway workers in mind.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dicks|first1=Kevin|title=NELSON HANDBALL COURT|url=http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/32811/details/NELSON+HANDBALL+COURT/|website=Royal Commission on the ancient and historical monuments of Wales|language=English}}</ref>
===Professional development=== With Wales' industrial development, and the sport's continued popularity, vast numbers were now able spectate or compete and yet more players became professionals, leading to great rivalries between communities.
One of the first names of national renown was Richard Edwards ("''champion of every church yard in [[Denbighshire]]''"). Local champions like Billy Newnam of [[Llantrisant]] and the ''"terrible Treharne twins"'' of [[Pontypridd]] also enjoyed widespread fame and adulation. It was common for competitors to travel between villages and towns to challenge the champions of other localities, often for large sums of money.
By the 1870s, Dr Ifor Ajax-Lewis of Llantrisant and Richard Andrews, a miner from [[Nelson, Caerphilly|Nelson]] were offering enormous prize money to any player who could beat them. Andrews, known affectionately as ''‘Dic Ted’'' was particularly admired. Playing throughout the 1870s he played in many famous matches such as that against the 19 year old Peter Price. Peter was another miner at the nearby Taff Bargoed colliery, and their showdown was played in front of an especially large crowd at the Harp Inn in [[Gelligaer]]. Andrews also played against W Jones of [[New Tredegar]] for the then record purse of £20.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dicks|first1=Kevin|title=Handball – The Story of Wales’ First National Sport|date=2017|publisher=Y Lolfa|isbn=9781784613761}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Difford|first1=Carl|title=Handball: Wales’ first national sport|url=http://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/news/features/15411358.Handball__Wales____first_national_sport/|website=South Wales Argus}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Tony Collins|author2=Emma Lile|author3=Annette Walsh|title=Encyclopedia of Traditional British Rural Sports|date=2005|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0-415-35224-X|pages=143–144|url=https://books.google.com/?id=NWu6sLJn7-kC&pg=PA144&lpg=PA144&dq=welsh+handball+pel-llaw#v=onepage&q=welsh%20handball%20pel-llaw&f=false}}</ref>
===Decline and revivals===
Wales endured great economic and cultural changes in the early twentieth century, with the boom [[Edwardian era|Edwardian years]] (which saw the Welsh population grow more than 20%) followed by [[World War I|war]], [[Post–World War I recession|economic uncertainty]] and numerous industrial disasters.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jenkins|first1=James O|title=Pêl-law|url=http://www.afinebeginning.com/pel-law/|website=A Fine Beginning|language=English}}</ref> This societal turmoil was reflected by a decline in traditional Welsh activities such as Pêl-law, while further advances in transportation made it easier for teams and supporters to travel to the increasingly popular team sports like [[Rugby Union|Rugby]].
[[The Great Depression]] saw a notable revival however, with Pêl-law again becoming popular as an informal and almost costless street game for impoverished workers. The revival was especially prevalent in the [[Swansea]] area, where street versions were a notable feature throughout the city as late as the 1960s.
Another revival began with the formation of the Welsh Handball Association in 1987 to both preserve the Welsh game and coordinate international matches with nations playing similar games to Pêl-law. In 1995 markings for One Wall Handball were made within the three-walled Nelson court and in May that year the inaugural European One Wall Handball Tournament was held in Wales. Attended by representatives from Ireland, England, Belgium and even the USA. The tournament was based at Nelson, with [[Caerphilly]] and [[Bargoed]] also hosting matches.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Moore|first1=Joe|title=The Handball Court at Nelson|journal=The Green Dragon|date=December 1996|volume=1|issue=1|url=http://www.ballinagree.freeservers.com/handnelson.html|language=English}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Hughes|first1=Tony|title=The 1995 European One Wall Handball Championships|url=http://www.fivesonline.net/oldefasite/articles/onewall.html|website=fivesonline.net}}</ref> The new international competitions saw Welsh success in 1997 when Nelson's Lee Davies (Welsh champion throughout the 1990s) became World Champion.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jenkins|first1=James O|title=Pêl-law|url=http://www.afinebeginning.com/pel-law/|website=A Fine Beginning|language=English}}</ref>
==Courts==
Local courts were simply known as ''Y Plaen'' (The plain) or ''Plaen Pêl'' (Ball plain) hosted singles and doubles matches and tended to be three walled, but one walled courts were also built. Today many of the surviving courts are unplayable, with possibly the Nelson Court being the only one to be continually maintained.
===The Nelson Court===
The Old Ball Court in [[Nelson, Caerphilly|Nelson]] is a three-sided handball court constructed c.1860. The unique design is based upon the earlier court at the yard of the Nelson Inn. The landlord of the Royal Oak constructed the new court to entice more customers, especially from the Nelson Inn.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dicks|first1=Kevin|title=NELSON HANDBALL COURT|url=http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/32811/details/NELSON+HANDBALL+COURT/|website=Royal Commission on the ancient and historical monuments of Wales|language=English}}</ref>
The court elevated Nelson to a major center for the game with all the great players of their day gracing the court accompanied by large excited crowds and much betting. The Nelson court was also famous for its annual tournaments held between May and August and accompanied by high levels of gambling. The court length was reduced in the 1990s due to safety concerns from the increasing traffic through the village.
In May 1995 the first European Handball Tournament was held at Nelson and was attended by American, Belgian, English, Irish and Welsh teams. Recent notable players include Lee Davies, who was Welsh champion throughout the 1990s and became World Handball Champion in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jenkins|first1=James O|title=Pêl-law|url=http://www.afinebeginning.com/pel-law/|website=A Fine Beginning|language=English}}</ref>
The Eton Fives Yearbook (1994–95) commented, ''“admittedly the weather was excellent, but I would ask you to envisage a court situated right in the middle of a Welsh village, with a local pub literally on the left hand side of the court and a row of terraced houses on the right, and the main road and shops behind. On Finals day you could mingle with the local spectators. We saw the soul of handball in Wales this May. This year the court there became the centre of village life. We saw the game as it was originally devised, a street game, a game of the people.”''
Today, the game remains a unique feature of the village with a seating area built for spectators in 2010.
===Jersey Marine===
Another surviving handball court is Burrows Court in [[Jersey Marine]]. The Court was built in 1864 by brewery owner [[Evan Evans (brewery)|Evan Evans]]. The court features a stone heart set in the highest wall and an inscription which reads ''Gwrol Galon Hyd Angau'' (a brave heart till death). This emblem is that of the 17th Glamorgan Volunteer Rifle Corps and it is thought that the court may have been used as a rifle range for the volunteers’ target practice.
It was here in 1875 that Dr Ivor Ajax-Lewis, the handball champion for Llantrisant, defeated Mr Lovett, the champion of Neath, in a celebrated match with £1,000 in betting stakes.
==Further reading== *'Porth and Rhondda Fach' by Aldo Bacchetta and Glyn Rudd. Pages 22–23. The Most Famous Handball Court in South Wales. *The Encyclopedia of British Sport. Richard Cox, Grant Jarvie & Wray Vamplew. Pages 416-417. Welsh Handball. *'A Whole Different Ball Game'. 1995 BBC Radio Wales. Produced by Gareth Whittock. *H. J. Jones, Nelson Handball Court 1860–1940. History of the Court and its Players. *T. Vaughan Jones: ‘Handball and Fives’ p. 22 (unpublished). *John Newman, The Buildings of Wales: Glamorgan, 1995, p573.

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = World Chess Boxing Organisation |image = Logo wcbo 170px.png |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = WCBO |motto = Fighting is done in the ring and wars are waged on the board |formation = {{start date and age|2003}} |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Berlin]], [[Germany]] |location = |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Iepe Rubingh]] |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{url|http://www.wcbo.org/}} |remarks = }} The '''World Chess Boxing Organisation''' ('''WCBO''') is the [[Sport governing body|governing body]] of the new sport [[chess boxing]]. The WCBO was founded in 2003 and has its headquarters in [[Berlin, Germany]]. Its current president is [[Iepe Rubingh]], founder of the sport.
The principal tasks of the WCBO include: training people in the number one thinking sport and the number one fighting sport and the combination of both; building up a worldwide structure of chess boxing clubs and organisations; promoting chess boxing; and holding championship and promotional fights.
Currently, there are two organisations that are affiliated to the WBCO: *the Chess Boxing Club Berlin (founded in August 2005) *the [[Bulgaria]]n Chess Boxing Organisation (founded in October 2005)
The WCBO's motto is: "Fighting is done in the ring and wars are waged on the board".
